para.para.body: The subset S of the plane below consists of a grid of horizontal and vertical points all of which have the same distance from their neighbors. Is S closed under addition?
Yes! - S is closed under vector addition.

Consider any two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} whose tail is at the origin (the red dot) and whose tip is at any one of the dots in S . The question is: is the tip of \Vect{x}+\Vect{y} also at one of the dots in S ?

The set S below consists of the rectangle shown below (including its interior). Is it closed under addition?
The set S is not closed under vector addition.
Consider any two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} whose tail is at the origin (the red dot) and whose tips are in S . The question is: is the tip of \Vect{x}+\Vect{y} also in S ?
The picture below shows that S contains two vectors whose sum is not in S . Therefore S is not closed under addition.

More generally, whenever a set S contains a nonzero vector \Vect{x} and fits inside some box, S cannot be closed under addition. Why? Adding up sufficiently many copies of x yields a vector outside of S .
Is the set S below consisting of the rectangle below closed under scalar multiplication?
No! - S is not closed under scalar multiplication.
If S is closed under scalar multiplication and contains a nonzero vector \Vect{x} , then S must also contain the entire line through the origin in the direction of \Vect{x} .
S contains a nonzero vector, for example the one displayed below.
The line through the origin in the direction of \Vect{x} is not entirely contained in S . Therefore S is not closed under scalar multiplication.
Let S be the collection of points in the ellipse below. Is S closed under addition?
No, S is not closed under addition.
Let S consist of the family of parallel lines below. The distance of any line from its two neighbors is the same. Is S closed under addition?
Yes, S is closed under vector addition.
The picture below suggests that the sum of any two vectors in S is again a vector in S .

A more rigorous argument runs as follows: Points in S have position vectors of the form s \Vect{a} + t \Vect{b} , where s\in \RNr and t is an integer. Adding two such vectors yields again the position vector of a point in S :
which is again of the form of a vector in S .

Alternatively, you can show that P fails to be closed under vector addition.

For each of the sets of vectors below determine if it is a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
The set L of all vectors \Vect{x} = (x,y,z) with x=1+t , y=2t , and z=-t , with t\in\RNr arbitrary.
No! – L is not a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
Review the defining properties of a subvector space.
Does L contain the \Vect{0} -vector?
The set L consists of all vectors \Vect{x} of the form
It is the line in \RNr[3] through (1,0,0) in the direction of (1,2,-1) . This line does not contain the \Vect{0} -vector: The vector equation
has no solution. Therefore L is not a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
Test if L is closed under scalar multiplication.
If \Vect{x} is on L , you need to test if s\cdot \Vect{x} is in L for every s in \RNr .
We test if L is closed under scalar multiplication. For example, setting t:=0 tells us that \Vect{x}=(1,0,0) is on L . However,

Comment You may also check that every vector \Vect{x} on L has the property that s\cdot \Vect{x} is on L if and only if s=1 . So L fails to be closed under scalar multiplication with respect to every vector on L .
Test if L is closed under vector addition.
If you pick two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} on L , you need to test if \Vect{x} + \Vect{y} is on L .
We test if L is closed under vector addition. Let \Vect{x} = (1+t,2t,-t) be arbitrary on L . Then \Vect{x}+\Vect{x} fails to be on L because the vector equation
has no solution. Therefore L is not closed under vector addition. Hence it is not a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
The set Q of vectors \Vect{x} = (x,y,z) in \RNr[3] with x=\pi t , y=2t^2 , and z=t , where t\in\RNr is arbitrary.
No! Q is not a subvector space of \RNr[3] .

The set \Pi of vectors \Vect{x} = (x,y,z) in \RNr[3] with z=-x+y .
Yes! – \Pi is a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
Is \Pi the orthogonal complement of a subset of \RNr[3] ?
We claim that \Pi is a subvector space of \RNr[3] . To see this, we note that \Vect{x}=(x,y,z) belongs to \Pi exactly when
This happens exactly when \Vect{x} belongs to the hyperspace of \RNr[3] which is perpendicular to the vector \Vect{t}:=(1,-1,1) . So \Pi = \Vect{t}^{\bot} is a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
The set Z of vectors \Vect{x} = (x,y,z) in \RNr[3] with x-y+z=-1 .
No! – Z is not a subvector space of \RNr[3] .
Does Z contain the origin of \RNr[3] ?
Check that Z is a hyperplane of \RNr[3] . – How is this hyperplane related to the set \Pi in the previous problem?
If V and W are subspaces of \RNr[n] , show that the union of V and W need not be a subvector space of \RNr[n] .
The problem asks you to show that not every pair V and W of subspaces of \RNr[n] has the property that the union of V and W is a subspace of \RNr[n] .
It is sufficient to find a number n and then two specific subspaces V and W of \RNr[n] whose union is not a subspace.
It is possible to show this for n=2 .
In \RNr[2] , let V be the x -axis, and let W be the y -axis. Is the union of V and W closed under vector addition?
